awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Data Driven Remanufacturing: Foundation for Modeling the Impact of Product Middle-of-Life Data on End-of-Life Recovery Decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
1705621 (Behdad). The objective of this research is to create a framework for application of middle-of-life product data toward making sustainable product end-of-use recovery and reuse/recycle/etc. decisions. The framework to be developed has three main components: 1) Data collection: the definitions of different types of data that are generated over the middle-of-life phase of the product, particularly from the consumers' usage behavior, and also the types of uncertainty included in the data; 2) Data analytics: the evaluation of future reusability of consumer electronics based on usage profiles; and 3) Decision-making techniques: the identification of the best End of Use (EOU) options (e.g., reuse, recycle, remanufacture, refurbish, and disposal) not only based on product reusability, but also planned-obsolescence and market acceptance. Several application areas will be studied with the help of an industry partner. The focus will be on collecting consumer usage data for charge and discharge usage of lithium-ion laptop batteries and Hard Disk Drives (HDDs) data from home-run and office-run personal computers. This research is targeted to allow information flow to go beyond the first product lifecycle and to feed the information gathered in the first lifecycle to remanufacturing decisions being made at the start of the future lifecycles. Particularly, a prognostic method will be developed that predicts the future reusability of different components of a product, aggregates the data together and further optimizes the appropriate EOU option.

The research will include three major activities: 1) Characterizing product usage behavior of consumers to identify general product usage patterns. Data will be collected from surveys and information collected by industry partners on the specific category of electronic devices to quantify the conditions under which  certain electronics have been used; 2) Creating a new class of predictive modeling techniques to quantify the future reusability of products based on the lifecycle profile and consumer usage behavior, and developing a set of decision models in the form of prognostic algorithms to determine the best EOU recovery option for used products incorporating the reusability assessment as well as the information from product technical life, market life, design life and physical life; and finally 3) Evaluating the proposed decision-making methods. This research has potential in facilitating the reusability of consumer electronics. These practices are essential for responding to the growing global hunger for electronic devices in newly industrialized countries that lack the sufficient systems, policies and infrastructure for appropriate management and recovery of electronic waste (e-waste). With the help of an industry partner, the project seeks to advance remanufacturing by providing massive and heterogeneous industry data 
in a challenging e-waste application area.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Project Objective: Electronic waste (e-waste) recycling and remanufacturing plants often receive used electronics with different models, conditions, ages, and quality levels. It is challenging for remanufacturers to precisely determine the future reusability of each incoming product, and identify what would be the best end-of-use (EOU) recovery decision for each device (e.g. reuse, recycle, refurbish, disposal). The objective of this project was to understand the role of product lifecycle data, particularly data from the usage phase and consumer behavior, in enhancing the chance of extending the product lifecycle by remanufacturing and giving them a new life. With a particular focus on addressing the e-waste issue, the project developed a set of decision-making methods to help remanufacturers use the data collected during the product's usage phase and previous life of devices in making appropriate EOU recovery decisions.

Research Outcomes: In collaboration with experts from the recycling and remanufacturing industry, the research team has been involved in three main research activities: (1) data collection, (2) data analytics, and (3) the development of decision-making models.

The project envisions future IoT-enabled waste management practices where collecting product lifecycle data facilitates reducing waste and enhancing resource recovery. A combination of survey studies and industry datasets has been used to gather the raw research data. Then, data mining techniques, predictive modeling tools, and simulation models have been built to help remanufacturers compute the chance for reusing and remarketing each device. The project case studies have been focused on three main categories of products: consumer electronics, lithium-ion batteries, and medical devices. Further, a set of decision models have been developed to help remanufacturers determine the best recovery option for each device based on future reusability as well as market analysis and environmental considerations. 

A wide range of research outcomes has been generated. To name a few, the economic leakage as a result of insufficient recycling of hard disk drives has been quantified; the average energy loss of single-use batteries due to the early disposal and remaining energy inside has been calculated; the factors influencing remanufacturers in deciding on whether to repair or replace medical equipment has been studied; consumer acceptance of product-service systems has been analyzed; the impact of manufacturer's pricing policies and repair cost on consumer decisions to repair mobile phones has been studied; moreover, a set of data-driven decision-making frameworks have been developed in integration with advancing data science techniques.

Twelve journal papers, seven peer-reviewed full conference papers, over six conference presentations, one book chapter, and over ten seminars, talks, and poster presentations have resulted from this project.

Educational Outcomes: Five Ph.D., seven Master's, and six undergraduate students have received mentorships as part of the research activities related to this project. The project provides students the opportunity to work in multidisciplinary teams, present their work in academic conferences, and collaborate with members from the remanufacturing industry. In addition, the outcomes of this project have been integrated into several courses including Decision-based Design, Sustainable Manufacturing, System Analysis for Sustainable Design and Lifecycle Decisions, and Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Environmental Engineers. 


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Sara Behdad
